Comment: The link is referencing SSTs (sea surface temperatures), not ocean heat content. And they are short-term fluctuations that are being observed, not trends. It is rather normal for SSTs to rise and fall over the short term with ENSO and other teleconnection transitions. Your reference states this:

"...we see downward spikes in ocean temps everywhere, led by sharp decreases in the Tropics and SH, reversing the bump upward last month."

Aside from the fact that author did not make the distinction that I first noted, what he is noting is noise, not signal. Over the short term, the noise is up and down. Filter that noise, and you see the signal. Here is that signal (the trend):

http://www.woodfortrees.org/graph/hadsst3gl/plot/hadsst3gl/trend

This is the same mistake that you made with the sea level bit. This may help:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e0vj-0imOLw

Comment: The 'Star-Spangled Banner'--the original unexpurgated version--includes death-threats to runaway slaves seeking refuge among the British. Logical to conclude it would have a 'special' meaning to many black Americans, past and present.

Similarly the flag, as many have pointed out, can have different connotations to different people. I would argue it stood as a symbol of betrayal and murder to the peaceful Cheyenne and Arapaho elders, women and children who huddled beneath it in their final moments at Sand Creek, Colorado.

I fail to see how the meanings Trent Lott or Newt Gingrich ascribe to the flag are more acceptable than the Cheyennes'. It certainly didn't help them as they sought shelter beneath it, crying for mercy. Nor will it help us to hide behind the flag from the bitter truths of this nation's crimes.

Mark Twain, horrified by US atrocities in the Philippines campaign, remarked the US flag should be redesigned--from the 'Stars and Stripes' to the Skull and Crossbones.

Comment: This situation happened yesterday at my school in Ottawa. 
Scenario: Parent is loading up vehicle with child (toddler) and belongings. The wind blows the door shut. The key fob and child are locked inside the car. The parent became frantic because he believes that the child could asphyxiate in a closed vehicle. He phones 9-1-1 and explains the situation. I come on the scene and help the parent provide location details to dispatch and reassure him that the child will definitely NOT asphyxiate, and heat is not currently a concern due to the overcast day and mild temperature. The operator provides a number for the parent to call the Canadian Automobile Association. Turns out that CAA in Ottawa offers free door unlocking any time you have a child or pet trapped in a locked vehicle. The CAA tow-truck and driver show up within 10 minutes. The doors are quickly unlocked. Dad and son are reunited. Happy ending for everyone and Dad gets extra keys cut for his car.

Comment: Implementing an income tax while distributing a PFD check is a wealth redistribution scheme. I support the Alaska Senate saying no to an income tax (or sales tax) so long as a PFD check is distributed. We have a University system that we cannot afford, we have an education system that is far too expensive and needs to be reigned in, and there are some additional cuts to State Government that can and should be made. 

That said, I am in agreement that we cannot simply cut our way out of our problem. The PFD checks should end or be reduced to a level that we can afford, and we should allow the Permanent Fund to continue to increase in size until it can support State Government going forward. If it takes an income tax in addition to deleting the PFD to get there then I am fine with that.

Comment: The effects of fluoride are both topical and systemic.  The systemic effects are demonstrated in mild to very mild dental fluorosis optimally fluoridated water.  As peer-reviewed science has demonstrated mildly fluorosed teeth to be more decay resistant, many consider this effect to not even be undesirable, much less adverse.  Dental fluorosis can only occur systemically. 
.
—-The Association Between Enamel Fluorosis and Dental Caries in U.S. Schoolchildren Hiroko Iida, DDS, MPH and Jayanth V. Kumar, DDS, MPH
.
Additionally, saliva with fluoride incorporated into it provides a constant bathing of the teeth in a low concentration of fluoride all throughout the day, a very effective means of dental decay prevention. Incorporation of fluoride into saliva occurs systemically.
.
Recommendations for Using Fluoride to Prevent and Control Dental Caries in the United States
US Centers for Disease Control
Recommendations and Reports
August 17, 2001/50(RR14);1-42

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: Normally, I'm quicker than most to get outraged when the City adds yet another regressive fixed base charge to every household, rich and poor alike.  But this time, I think the new charge is both moderate and very sensible.

If the City loses its current fire insurance rating, as it definitely will if we don't fix staffing, we will all pay a much bigger $ penalty than this in insurance premium hikes (which also get passed on in rent increases).  Adding four good local jobs, which will feed our economy while it makes our community safer, just makes sense.  And it's cheap at the price.

It's also important to remember that when any major catastrophe happens, it's the Fire Department that bears the brunt of rescuing people from cave-ins, dealing with hazmat incidents, treating the injured and getting them to hospital  --  I'm saying that this is not a good function to economize on.  We need these guys.

Comment: Prior to retirement I worked for a large financial organization. The organization needed to know about competitors products so I was the corporate go-to guy for questions on the structure, function and taxation of all investments. I still have that info and our retirement capital is now 2.5X higher than at retirement.  Two years ago I bought annuities with 2 of my RRIFs. They are joint and last survivor with a 10 year guarantee. That means they pay a level income as long as either I or my wife live. If we both die before 10 years, the remaining value is paid to our daughters. There was little difference in the incomes, however the RRIF pays a decreasing income until depletion of the capital while the annuity payments remain constant. There are sites where you can get payout numbers for both annuities and for RRIFS. Set the capital and income requirements the same for each calc and take a look at the numbers in 5, 10 and 15 years. Take a 10 year guarantee on the annuity.no space left

Comment: Your response appears to be intentionally facetious, however it's not particularly clever as it appears none of the scandals you cite directly intersect with the power or role of the GG. Harper's prorogation antics, on the other hand, illustrate why constitutional monarchy does nothing to protect the integrity of the Canadian political system. Harper demonstrated that a PM can effectively ignore the role that's in theory reserved for the monarch's representative. Whatever the views of those who opposed the putative coalition that was waiting in the wings at the time, in the most infamous case of Harper's machinations the GG should have insisted that the legislature be convened to decide the government's fate (which interestingly in the method by which BC's Lib government was recently dumped). Harper, though, insisted on prorogation so he could buy time to discredit the coalition and the GG was powerless to stop him, rendering the institution of monarchy utterly redundant in Canada.

Comment: NDAs (and non-competes) are pretty much never worth the paper they are printed on. They are genuinely unenforcible contracts in almost all cases.

The only real power they have is that, should you violate them, the entity you signed them for can sue you. They'll almost always lose if it goes to trial (globally they almost always do) - but that will be a very large amount of money and time later - and a lot of legal fees.
Most people can't afford a legal fight with a government department or large corporation so the vast majority are settled out of court.

And because people know that, most people obey NDAs and non-competes because it would be too expensive to deal with the difficulties (and no guarantee) of showing the contracts are not, in fact, legal.

But as a standard rule - never sign an NDA because you can only get screwed by a contract that's got all the legality of used toilet paper.

Comment: "You don't almost triple the national debt in a decade by 'paying interest'."
Actually, yes you do if the nominal interest is compounding faster than you can pay down the principal; it's grade school mathematics.

Mulroney inherited Revenue - program expenses of - 2.7%. It fell to -1.2% in his first budget, -0.2% in his second, and went into surplus of 0.4% in his third

Consolidated deficit went from 8.1% in Trudeau's last budget, fell to 6.7% in Mulroney's first, to 5.7% in his second, and 5.1% in his third.

So if Revenue - Program expenses is positive 0.4% and the Consolidated budget in negative 5.1%, what is pushing you to deficit? Answer: Interest on PET's debt.

Comment: Look closely at the details describing the Cafferatas' work; I think they're doing a little better than you what you credit here.

They seem concerned with protecting biodiversity, for instance. They preserve hardwoods that will  lessen yield because wildlife thrive in them. They plant willows for birds and bugs. They CUT blackberries and scotch broom, instead of spraying. 

And they are planting the slower-growing species--cedars, hemlock. redwoods-- that made up the old growth, not just Douglas Firs. They're doing a lot of what needs to be done to restore the land to actual forests, instead of just planting more tree farms and mistaking them for forests.

Comment: Good reminder, John. Canadians shouldn't touch U.S. MLPs with a ten foot pole - been there and got the T-shirt during my random, idea of the day investing days.

For people that are looking for robust yields from U.S. stocks I would suggest that they look at U.S. BDCs (business development companies) and U.S. mREITs (mortgage REITS). Higher average dividends than MLPs without any of the drawbacks.

Some suggested names to look at are:

BDCs - ARCC, MAIN, GSBD (piggy back on the big boys).
MREITs - AGNC, NLY, BXMT, STWD.

Disclosure - I own them all. But note these are not low risk stocks - dividends can fluctuate (driven by the fact that both have to pay out 90% of earnings each year) - but I would not characterise them as high risk either. I've held a bunch (7 REITs and 8 BDCs) for years  and have been fully satisfied with the performance.

Primarily yield plays - not going to see material capital appreciation.

Comment: This article seems to be extremely disingenuous, taking quotes out of context and offering interpretation for them.  

For instance, he did not suggest "that many prominent Catholics are so weak in their faith that they ought to leave the church."  

What he actually said was "Losing people who are members of the Church in name only is an imaginary loss. It may in fact be more honest for those who leave and healthier for those who stay. We should be focused on commitment, not numbers or institutional throw-weight. We have nothing to be afraid of as long as we act with faith and courage."

Nor did he say anything about a church of "fewer but holier believers" being  preferable.  That is Mr. Gibson's spin.  Better to read the speech yourself and then make your determinations.  Most here are not going to agree with him - that is their choice - but read what he actually said.

https://www.romancatholicman.com/courageous-archbishop-chaputs-speech-watershed-moment-american-catholics/

Comment: Okay, let’s get serious. Over the last few years, we have seen one baseless police killing after another. Mostly, these killings occur because police are trained to act aggressively and place themselves into situations of immediate risk and thus make split second decisions which, as we see, often lead to needless death. Despite protests, nothing has been done to alter police tactics so as to be more life friendly. Unfortunately, sometimes it is necessary to fight fire with fire to produce change. I think probably many of us expected a war against police to break out. I expect it will continue until real attention is paid to change police tactics. Police do not have to be as aggressive as they are except in rare situations. The routine massive show of deadly force causes many unnecessary deaths,

When injustice becomes massive, eventually, the victims of the injustice fight back. We have seen that here. The best response would be to consider fixing the problem.

No one is suggesting reducing the Transfer. The plan is that it will increase by at least 3% a year.

Comment: My memory is not so good either. You a getting more data which is good. It should be noted that this garden is in an area with a lot of vegetation so temperatures will be lower and relative humidity higher than some environments.

It may turn out that water consumption and added pollution are not problems but it would be good to have numbers before mandating a policy.

I support the DA position that a majority of MP's should be beholden to their CONSTITUENCIES rather than to the party, but I nevertheless feel that the 75/25 split will certainly be outdated if the Motion-of-no-Confidence in Zuma SUCCEEDS this time around and the ANC splits between pro-Zuma and anti-Zuma factions etc, etc.
If we now have elections this year there should not only be a strong drive to implement mixed constituency-based and list-based MP's in future elections, but the number of ministeries should also be constitutionally limited to 25 to 30 ministeries. Comment: Absolutely right, T. . The Church is not the Holy Spirit. And thank God for it. The Church comprises good and evil...and the Spirit is not evil.

The Spirit is certainly WILLING (I would use italics here, but don't know how to access them on my new tablet) to preserve the Church from doctrinal error, but cannot do so if the Church will not listen to it. The Spirit, as Dennis Gahon made clear elsewhere, respects human free will. So if the Church is not willing to listen to the Spirit (and it still doesn't in at least one fundamental respect), then (as Dennis pointed out, too), its interactions with the Spirit will contain more of itself than the wisdom of God.

I prefer the earlier translations, T., not because they support my rendering of Jesus' recorded words, but because the nearer, linguistically, one is to the original languages, the more likely the reliability of the translation. Koine Greek is nearer in this respect than Latin.

Comment: No these realtors in Alaska are placing to high of a market value on these homes. You have homes built in 80s and 70s with a combined appraisal of land/building at 310k yet it's market price is over 500k. Realtors commonly argue that $/sq foot means nothing but it does when coupled with local averages and sq footages. 
Also a majority of these homes drop huge percentages usually 10% per month! Zillows great for showing a homes price history. One house listed 450k didnt sell after dropping to 400k. Relisted with another company for 420...drops to 390k. 6 months later the homes at 340k. 110k drop which is still 60k over appraisal. This is what equates to the buyer maxing the loan value of the house. In some instances 140% over value...this is what kills housing markets. I was in florida for their housing bubble...sooner than later no one will be able to get out of their homes unless the market reacts to the overpricing. Which it might now that interest rates are climbing.

Comment: Right, obviously at the present time our economy is dependent on tourism. But it's a fair question to ask, if hardly anyone wants tourism to be our bread and butter should Hawaii continue to blindly pursue it and ignore or put substantially less effort towards those sectors most of us do want to grow? 

And even if we agree that tourism is to remain the primary economic driver in Hawaii do we need to grow it continually? Or is some level of visitors a sufficient amount to insure a stable economy? And if tourism has associate economic negative externalities--and it does everything does--should Hawaii continue to ignore these? 

Nothing exists in a vacuum. Hawaii is dependent on tourists, but we develop that dependency. If we will not take action to reduce that dependency we should at least try to reduce the problems that said dependency causes us. HTA's desire to constantly increase tourism gives us a diminishing return just as the costs of additional tourists begins to rise.

Comment: I think what you write is true to a point, but there is a darker reason too.  Central banks need rates to rise over the remainder of good times so that they have some room to lower rates in the next crisis.

keeping track of the asymmetry of rate hikes versus cuts we have moved to what appears to be about parity. In 2015 when Yellen first introduced the issue it looked like a 25 basis point rise in rates was about equal to a 100 basis point drop,  as evidenced by the markets reaction and her backing off.

Central banks do not focus on bubbles per se either, or income equality.  Those are left to markets and governments respectively.

Markets stumble on average about every 7 or 8 years, and we are due.  Italy is in crisis.  Brexit is an ongoing crisis.  North Korea and the Middle East are not getting resolved. Trump remains a wild card.

Higher rates provide central bankers with the dry powder that they need to fight the next fight whatever that may be.

Comment: I don't find that argument ("wouldn't employers hire cheap women") persuasive, although I remain uncertain how much overt discrimination affects pay (some, for sure). Boggs posits a "perfect capitalism" where employers seek only to maximize revenue per dollar. But if women are being overtly discriminated against, then that could just as easily affect hiring practices as much as pay practices. In the sciences, studies have shown that just changing the perceived gender of an applicant will affect hiring and mentoring decisions, from both men and women. These barriers might be enough to reduce the "perfect capitalist's" desire for maximal profit.

A fetus is not a child, an adult is not a teen, an old man is not a young adult. Those terms refer to the appearances of the human person at different stages of their life.

Comment: I am concerned about environmental issues which includes concern about programs that do not do as intended or have unintended negative effects since there are those who use such programs to doubt all claims.
If a program is to become a mandate those who make the proposal should have readily available data and models to show that such a program will have the positive outcome with few negative ones. Even if something works in San Francisco or Chicago, Denver is at a higher altitude, with less precipitation and humidity with higher daytime temperatures and lower night time temperatures. That means that there will be some reduction in water to move downstream.  This value should be estimated for the public to know. There should be a comparison of energy differences between solar panels and green roofs (perhaps a paper for you and the Botanic garden).
The issue is if the public is to make a significant fiscal decision it should be based on sound data.

Comment: Aiea7, not sure to whom you are responding. If your comment is aimed at me, you misread my post. I specifically wrote:

"Caldwell decided to hike the property tax 70% on anyone renting a house assessed at over $1 million, Those are middle-class people in Hawaii's housing market."

While I am sympathetic to the idea of not hiking the property tax on owner-occupied houses, it is a mistake to pretend the Residential A tax hike is narrowly targeting "wealthy investors" when  is often hitting middle-class renters. 

It is a basic principle in tax policy to tax "at the margin." The Residential A tax kicks in immediately once inflation raises the value of a non-owner-occupied house above $1 million. That leads to absurd and abrupt tax hikes. If they are borne by "the super-rich," I will cry no tears. But it is unjust to try to balance the city's budget on the back of middle-income renters.

Comment: I drive W 6th and 7th Ave. every day, and have for many years. I am familiar with how long it used to take to traverse those streets and how long it takes now. I conservatively estimate I will spend at least 25 hours per year more on those streets now than I did prior to the EMX installation. Multiply that by the thousands of drivers who use those streets each day and the wasted hours are vast. Additionally, my car uses more fuel since it is running that much longer. Even if each EMX were used to capacity by people who would otherwise drive, the extra fuel used by everyone else who still must drive would dwarf any fuel savings attributable to EMX. The fender benders caused by the disappearing left lanes on 6th and serpentine lanes on 7th add to the external costs of this EMX boondoggle. And I am sure the extra walking distance between EMX stops thrills its senior citizen and disabled users. What a waste of $100 million to build it, plus the additional costs to everyone else.

Comment: The danger in discussing Trump's behavior is that it's too easy to get obfuscated by politics. To be fair, the same is true of Bill Clinton. It is clear  both men behaved very badly,  probably criminally so, and neither should be allowed to rationalize away the serious allegations against them as the rambling of partisan enemies.

In the broadest of strokes, this is about the powerful being allowed to prey on the weak, the oldest form of human injustice. In this case, the victims are not inherently weak because they are women, but because of a culture that, despite its claims, still practices male privilege behind closed doors. 

Sunshine is the best -- and probably only -- cure. And it's very hard for sunshine to filter through all the political maneuvering. I pray for truth to win out, and I also pray that this issue isn't forgotten once the election is over. This isn't just about electing a precedent. It's also about addressing a massive societal sin.

Comment: As far as why your post may have been removed, Brett's talked about etiquette with reader comments in the past (http://www.civilbeat.org/2016/11/reader-rep-watch-what-you-say-or-face-the-obvious-consequences/)

I didn't see your initial post, but perhaps it's worth it to dwell on whether it met the criteria for proper discourse.

As far as the ethics go, it would have been simple to break the news quickly while giving credit to CB. The underlying issue is that the desire for credit is not only dishonest, but it can lead to hasty, possibly less developed/informed, reporting. Dishonesty at worst can extend beyond work ethic and into the actual work, so it's important to scrutinize even the most subjectively manini of things.

Here's a clip of Denzel Washington alluding to this https://www.washingtonpost.com/video/entertainment/denzel-washington-calls-upon-journalists-to-tell-the-truth/2016/12/14/b218db8e-c248-11e6-92e8-c07f4f671da4_video.html

Comment: College is great, you don't have to go to one that costs $120,000...

I worked and had a family while I got my CHEE, incurred some debt which I paid off relatively quickly.  I went to a City University, but a good one.  

College teaches people how to research and learn on their own, and how to use past examples and designs to build new things.  The specific facts I learned in college are rarely used 20 years later, but my ability to comprehend and learn complex things...to communicate with words and pictures is invaluable.  

A degree helps in the job market, you get onto lists that folks without a degree can't get on.  Hiring is often a process of elimination.  Whether you go to college or not you are going to have a boss, and you are just a resource.  You can work in a sweatshop or a velvet sweatshop, and a very small percentage will make it to the very upper echelons.  However, I don't want to be there with those people.  Early bird catches worm, for the worm farmer.

Comment: Your misunderstanding of the purpose of audits amazes me. Auditors present an opinion on the fair presentation of financial statements (FS), ie there's no material misstatement and laws and regs are being adhered to ("clean"/unqualified audits). This is done this by examining, on a test basis (sampling), the financial records, accounting system and procedures, which are devised, designed and implemented by management, NOT auditor. The auditor states so in the intro paragraph of his report. 

So your statement "clean audits add to red tape" is incorrect on many levels. Red tape is not synonymous with an efficient and effective accounting system, which reduces organisational error and fraud and FS misstatement, promotes organisational  accountability, transparency and efficiency and assists the entity meet its strategic objectives. Or don't you want any of that? The auditor, a special kind of consultant, merely gives an opinion on the CLIENT'S system and its output, the FS.

Comment: We'll have to see what the NTSB concludes, but in general, low altitude takeoff turns are a bad idea. I hold my breath until 500' AGL, and start breathing normally again at 1000'. Unless there is some compelling reason, it's unwise on takeoff to start a turn at less than 500'. Even then, with a total loss of power, it would be difficult to react fast enough to get the ship back level, at the right glide speed, and land straight ahead under control. And without stalling, as that unforgiving ground comes up at you so fast. At 1000', at least you have a chance to try a re-start and to pick a landing spot.

I see air taxi cowboys all the time yanking their craft around at a few hundred feet on takeoff. Most all the time they get away with it, but if the engine goes silent, they and the passengers will be in for a very bad outcome.  

Non-pilot passengers may not comprehend a lot about the conduct of a flight, but they can note how quickly the pilot turns on takeoff. And avoid the cowboys.

Comment: I fail to see how the VPSO broke the law.  Law enforcement carry loaded guns.  They can draw loaded guns, and it sometimes doesn't even amount to an arrest, much less an assault.  

Law enforcement officers also have to protect themselves.  In this case, there were three people, with six hands, that could have done almost anything.  The VPSO had to protect himself.

If this was New York City, all three people would have been face down on the ground.  If the person tried to get up, he would know that he could be shot, without the police saying a word.  The VPSO here gave the three a verbal warning. 

While excessive force by law enforcement should be against the law, I don't see that here.  Moreover, the charges here could have a chilling effect on VPSOs from performing their law enforcement duties and protecting themselves.

The article suggests that taking photos was improper.  To the contrary, police should be required to video and audio record their investigations.

Comment: The funding of the Honolulu Zoo is a multi faceted issue that necessitates a certain amount of attention by it's managers - in this case the City and County of Honolulu. It is this perceived lack of attention to this jewel of Honolulu, and the effects from it, that is pushing this funding proposal onto the ballot. 

Is it the best way to fund the zoo? Well, I will say that there have been other proposals on the table before in which prior administrations have eschewed. Specifically a public private partnership based on the successful San Diego Zoo model. I remember this being a discussion point in the "mid-aughts" but went no where. 

Perhaps this is an idea that we should consider, again, to see to it that the Zoo remain a jewel of the city and not a continued source of angst by taxpayers, anxiety for those who use the zoo (a lot of local families and kids) and anger by residents on the city whenever bad news (like de-accreditation) happens to it.

Basically it does not  ...  it just gets smaller and smaller.  The pictures of albatross that have died on Midway due having their digestive systems clogged with bits of plastic is a harbinger of a huge die off in the larger food web ... due to plastic.  We need common sense long term solutions.  I suggest watching the film "Smog of the Sea".  It illustrates the global ubiquitous nature of plastic in our waste stream.  Note incinerating plastic creates poisonous gases.   i like the idea of containers made out of starch that we can eat.

Comment: Is it true that there's been a meltdown of humanity in Aleppo? Not within the context of war, there hasn't. Just look at the numbers. 

According to reports published elsewhere on this news site, over the past month 1,134 people were killed in Aleppo. This includes 583 civilians, 398 rebels and 153 soldiers and militiamen allied with the government. Of the 583 civilian deaths, 130 were caused by rebel shellings on western Aleppo. Simply put, that's a modest casualty level in the circumstances. The last time Israel mounted a major assault on Gaza in 2014, they killed 2100 Palestinians, including 1500 civilians, 498 of them children. The Israelis alone caused three times the civilian casualties that were killed by both sides in Aleppo! 

Urban warfare takes a high toll on civilian life. Despite all of the propaganda, Aleppo has been on the lower end of the scale.

Comment: Like any social welfare program (and rent control is effectively a transfer of capital from property owners to renters), once it is in place "temporarily" it will become permanent, guaranteed.  If you want to argue otherwise, specifically when and under what circumstances do you see the rent freeze actually expiring?  Because if it won't expire in reality, and it's also bad long-term policy (it hasn't worked at all to keep housing generally affordable in NYC, SF, or LA), it shouldn't be implemented in the short-term either.

There are also plenty of good mom-and-pop landlords who risk having their lifetime investment (and often significant portion of their savings in the form of equity) ruined when they have no swift recourse to deal with a problem tenant and/or an unexpected large expense like a systems replacement.  Is an eviction worse than a foreclosure?  The current state of affairs is not good, but in my opinion the draconian measures PTU is proposing in response are worse.

Comment: We should be radically Christian all the time.  

Fail and begin again is what Christians do!  It keeps us humble, leaving more room for God to work in.  Pride crowds out God. 

Read Romans 12 and sense it.  It's not the tenor of your notes to be sure.

We all fall short every day, but that doesn't mean we give up or whine or quit, or say "we won't until something somewhere else changes first". 

Read Romans 12...slowly and renew your sense for what St Paul was encouraging.

Parts of it read almost as if he was dictating it on horseback, galloping, unable to contain the Holy Spirit coming out of his mouth. 

That's the spirit of Christianity..and it's not beyond any of us to implement this spirit (His spirit) heroically daily right where we are, immediately and always. 

Falling short, sure, but beginning again with Him tomorrow, or earlier. 

We shouldn't fool ourselves into thinking Rome needs to change before we can live this spirit, heroically, today/now, right here.

Comment: Economists have always had difficulty showing that increases in the minimum wage cause much job loss. That might change with Oregon's new minumum. The median wage in Oregon is around 45000, or about 21.50 per hour. That's uncomfortably close to the new minimum, leading one to believe this has the potential to be very disruptive to the labor market. I hope it doesn't, but this is uncharted territory. From everything I have read, the minimum should be about half of the median, which is about where Oregon was. But in its rush to pass this bill, the legislature took no testimony from an economist that I can find. Not a good idea.
